thread.title: B*Witched announce comeback for 20th anniversary and promise new music
thread.title_full: B*Witched announce comeback for 20th anniversary and promise new music

author: Alistair McGeorge
title: B*Witched announce comeback for 20th anniversary and promise new music
text:
B*Witched announce comeback for 20th anniversary and promise new music The C'est La Vie and Blame It On The Weatherman group are returning in a big way Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get celebs updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
B*Witched are to mark the 20th anniversary of their hit C'est La Vie with new music next year. 
The Blame it on the Weatherman hitmakers - who are made up of Lindsay Armaou, Sinead O'Carroll and sisters Keavy and Edele Lynch - have revealed their plans to mark the milestone with the release of some new tunes, which will reflect where they are "musically" now rather than in their heyday in the 90s. 
Edele, 37, said: "We're gonna be what we are now musically and what we feel now. B*Witched will celebrate their 20th anniversary (Photo: Rex Features) 
"We're not gonna try tap into what we were because that's nostalgia and the music industry has moved on so much as we all have ... we've updated it so we feel comfortable with it." Read More B*Witched thrill fans at G-A-Y with sexy Irish-themed performance for St Patrick's Day 
And while they are looking forward to celebrating two decades since the release of the 1998 number one, Edele admits she got "fed up" with getting the song stuck in her head. 
She confessed to the Daily Star newspaper: "I think it's incredible. I think at some point I was getting a little fed up with it, and two years ago I did pantomimes and we had C'est La Vie in the pantomime. BWitched celebrate St Partirck's Day performing a live show at G-A-Y last year (Photo: Chris Jepson/WENN.com) 
"But I wasn't in it, so I got to stand back and look at C'est La View from a different perspective." 
Like most pop groups they had their disagreements, Edele and Sinead particularly, but they managed to work things out when they reunited in 2012 for TV's The Big Reunion show and they've been close every since. 
She said: "We're the best of friends again now and I talk to Sinead in particular every day and I wouldn't want my life without her again." B*Witched don't want to be a nostalgia act 
Back then, Edele admitted their come back for the ITV2 show was ''very dramatic'', but they felt ''more together as a band''. 
She told BANG Showbiz: ''Before we started we got together all on camera and cleared lots of air. It's very dramatic and there's lots of emotions. It's been huge.'' 
Keavy added: ''But I feel more together as a band now than we did at the beginning of rehearsals because we weren't a band at all, so it was actually quite awkward.'' Like us on Facebook
